Older Driver Resources

  • American Association of Motor Vehicle Administrators: http://www.aamva.org/
  • American Association of Retired Persons: http://www.aarp.org or http://www.aarp.org/home-garden/transportation
  • American Automobile Association: www.seniordriving.aaa.com
    • AAA Driver licensing policies database: http://lpp.seniordrivers.org/lpp/

      • ADED http://www.driver-ed.org/
      • AOTA http://www.aota.org/Practice/Productive-Aging/Driving.aspx (has education on assessments)

Printed and Electronic Resources

  • We need to talk...Family conversation with older adults
    This guidebook provides families with easy-to-use, practical information to help them plan ahead and initiate productive and caring conversations with older adults about driving safely. Copies may be downloaded or ordered for FREE at: http://www.thehartford.com/mature-market-excellence/publications-on-aging
  • Older Driver Safety and Transition - for the Aging Network
    The National Center for Senior Transportation (NCST) has prepared two fact sheets on Older Driver Safety - with an emphasis on driving safely longer. This four-page document targets the provider community. This guide speaks to the aging network staff person, offering information and training about older driver safety and transitions useful to professionals and community agencies. Copies can be downloaded or ordered for FREE at: http://www.n4a.org/pdf/Older_Driver_Safety_and_Transition.pdf
  • Decisions About Driving: A Toolkit for Older Drivers and Their Families
    The American Academy of Family Physicians (AAFP) and the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) have developed FREE patient education materials for assessing older drivers. The packet, Decisions About Driving: A Toolkit for Older Drivers and Their Families, has five handouts that include tips on how senior citizens and their family members can cope after the older person has to stop driving, and checklists to assess driving skills (i.e., changes in vision, hearing, and general physical ability). The kits are available in packages of ten and can be ordered by calling 800-944-0000.
  • Transportation Options for Older Adults: Choices for Mobility Independence
    The brochure describes various types of transportation services for older adults and lists key questions to ask transportation provider to determine the best option to meet individual needs. Consumers may order up to five brochures at no charge. For organizations, items are available in free quantities as a one-time-only offer per organization. Shipping charges are extra. http://www.eldercare.gov/Eldercare.NET/Public/Resources/Brochures/Index.aspx
  • How to Help an Older Driver
    Discusses how families and friends of older drivers can help them maintain their independence and mobility without sacrificing safety. View PDF or order 10 FREE copies at: http://seniordriving.aaa.com/tools-additional-resources
  • Promising Approaches for Promoting Lifelong Community Mobility
    Produced by University of Michigan Transportation Research Institute with support from AARP, this guide highlights programs and initiatives that hold promise for enhancing the safety and mobility of older adults across the nation. Areas covered in the guide include driver screening and assessment, education and training, vehicle design and advanced technology, roadway design, transitioning from driving, transportation coordination, and alternative transportation options. To order FREE copies, call 1-888-OUR-AARP and ask for Stock #D18390 or at http://www.aarp.org/home-garden/transportation/info-7-2010/aarp_mobility_resources/
  • Drive Well Toolkit: Promoting Older Driver Safety and Mobility in Your Community
    The American Society on Aging (ASA) and the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) developed this Toolkit to understand the issues related to older drivers and later-life independence and mobility; plan and implement public information events for older drivers, their families and loved ones, and other community members and organizations; and evaluate the effectiveness of older driver public information events, community understanding of safe mobility issues, and progress in mobilizing community members – including older adults – to take action. PDF available at: http://www.nhtsa.gov/Driving+Safety/Older+Drivers/Drive+Well+Toolkit:+Promoting+Older+Driver+Safety+and+Mobility+in+ Your+Community
  • Transportation Solutions for Caregivers: A Starting Point
    Easter Seals' Transportation Solutions for Caregivers: A Starting Pointoffers a video, informational booklet and a list of helpful products and resources for family caregivers and volunteer drivers of older adults with cognitive and/or physical impairments. Available in PDF or power point at: http://seniortransportation.easterseals.com/site/PageServer?pagename=NCST2_tsc_toolkithome
  • At the Crossroads: The Support Group Leaders Kit on Alzheimer's Disease, Dementia and Driving
    This kit is a four-session educational workshop for delivery by support group leaders to caregivers on dementia and driving. Designed for practical application and based on solid evaluation research, the course is organized into three two-hour sessions with a total of nine lessons. Available only for group leaders at: http://hartfordauto.thehartford.com/Safe-Driving/Expertise-On-Getting-Older/Publications-And-Resources/#FamilyConvo
  • Keep Moving Longer: Features for Safe Driving
    DVD demonstrates a dozen low-tech vehicle modifications that may alleviate challenges with driving commonly experienced by aging motorists. Handout used to display modifications can be found at: http://cdn.umb.edu/images/FindingFeat.pdf
  • Roadwise Review: A Tool to Help Seniors Drive Safely Longer
    This CD-ROM program was created to help seniors drive safely longer and gives seniors the information they need to take responsibility for driving decisions and maintain their fitness behind the wheel. Copies are $5 and available at: https://www.aaafoundation.org/roadwise-review-online
  • Maturing of America Report 2011
    This annual report includes national information regarding communities included for the first time data on mobility management (i.e., person-centered counseling on transportation alternatives to driving). This is a relatively new strategy communities are implementing to identify alternatives to driving and find options suited to older adults’ needs. Its early stage of adoption is reflected in the fact that 75% of local governments report that this program is not available. Available for download at: http://www.n4a.org/files/MOA_FINAL_Rpt.pdf
  • AAA Resources
    • On-Line Defensive Driving Course
      On-line and on-ground courses and a self-rating tool for older drivers are offered by AAA. Visit: http://seniordriving.aaa.com/maintain-mobility-independence
    • Self-Rating Tool: http://seniordriving.aaa.com/evaluate-your-driving-ability/self-rating-tool
    • DriveSharp (clinically proven software program to help drivers): http://drivesharp.positscience.com/
    • Flexibility Fitness Training for Improving Older Driver Performance:
      https://www.aaafoundation.org/sites/default/files/flexibility_brochure.pdf
    • CarFit: http://www.car-fit.org/
  • Fit to Drive
    This brochure was developed by three researchers for the Missouri Department of Transportation. Available for download at: https://www4.modot.mo.gov/OrderSystem/pub/displayOrder.do
  • American Medical Association Physician’s Guide to Assessing and Counseling Older Drivers
    Developed for physicians, but applicable to all who work with older adults, this interactive curriculum is available at: http://www.ama-assn.org//ama/pub/physician-resources/public-health/promoting-healthy-lifestyles/geriatric-health/older-driver-safety/assessing-counseling-older-drivers.page
  • Medscape free curriculum on medications and driving
    http://www.medscape.org/viewprogram/31244
  • University of Florida
    Online tool for caregivers to assess older adult driving safety. Available at: http://fitnesstodrive.phhp.ufl.edu/ (background information on the tool available at: http://news.ufl.edu/2013/03/28/fit-to-drive/)

      http://www.safeandmobileseniors.org/index.htm
